commentBody: This was a Sunday to pad the average.
I could not solve any of the themers just from the clues.
I got hung up by insisting that Fuzz just HAD to be LINT.  But once I let that go, it went quickly, much quicker than my average Sunday solve

I don’t love these puzzles usually, but this one was ok. On Sunday, I always read the first part of Wordplay before starting. That was a help. I did enjoy the theme clues. Much better than my average time. Thanks!
For 29 Across, I’m stuck on “tree creature” but I have ENT in the circled boxes, which doesn’t make sense.
Cute. Faster than usual. I liked the themed clues! Clever.
hint, hint, this puzzle included a lot of great hints!  fun!

A very clever idea. I wonder if there has ever been a puzzle with one clue duplicated so many times. Perhaps, but I certainly don't recall. Not surprisingly, I needed the fewest crosses for NINE TIMES OUT OF TEN, since that at least is a common phrase. 

Such dependence on crosses reminded of those puzzles years ago with clues like “First part of the quip”, “Second part of the quip”, etc. They were usually very difficult.

A fun and unique clue for CHER, an entry which has appeared dozens of times, nine times out of ten with a boring clue. 

Nicely done, Mike.
i found it more annoying than clever. i did slog thru it though.
A lot faster than my average. I didn’t get any of the theme clues before having them filled in 2/3rds of the way. Fine enough Sunday.

A leisurely Sunday puzzle, with enough difficulty to keep me awake and interested. And distracted—I needed some respite from the daily news.

Nine times out of ten, people are better off without a top ranking royal. We should cast a really long look at our home near the sun and consider the pacifist's renouncement.

Thank you, Mike.  It was a great idea. You might say the cat's meow.

At first, I had PACIFISTS RENOUNCEMENT misspelled as PACIFASTS RENOUNCEMENT, thinking that some pacifists renounce food during FASTS, or hunger strikes. When I didn't get the little jingle after filling in the grid, I started painstakingly going through each entry to see what could be wrong. When I got to CIRRI, which I had misspelled as CIRRA, I knew I wasn't sure of the word, but that I needed a plural that did not end in "s." Luckily trying "i" did the trick!

Still quite a jaunty solve, though, even with my backtracking!
A little twee for me.
The first time I heard "popo" was when Kima said it in The Wire.
Enjoyable to solve and the themed answers were very clever. Loved 46A and 63A especially. Great job, Mike!
Big fan of words within words. Answers within clues within answers is quite a feat indeed. Very neat puzzle.

KEN??!! Too soon, too soon. Anyone else old enough to even consider ART?

Nice theme but honestly seemed fairly bland clues. I would have enjoyed it better with some longer/more/interesting inside clues even if it meant the letters weren’t consecutive

[Apt clue today for the capital letters]

THE MElding of clue and answer.
I didn't know "popo". Other than that, better than most gimmicks.
Is this where I file my complaint about BROEY in the Mini? What was that?
For a long while I had cOPs for “Fuzz”.

i did not enjoy this very much. I like a crossword puzzle that has clues for both across and down entries. I got stuck and there was nowhere to look because there was no cross. What fun is that? I'm losing my streak because I'm not going to finish it.
I don't get bald but the rest were good enough. Nice puzzle.

Would've been good if the themed entries were all actual phrases like TOP RANKING ROYAL. NINE TIMES OUT OF TEN was OK, but I would say that "often" refers to something less frequent - 6 or 7/10 perhaps...
Fine puzzle, maybe I just expect a bit more from a Sunday. Filled the time though, thanks.

For some reason the crossing of POE and POPO seemed amusing.

So I tried a Raven parody where the author is surprised by the popo rapping on his chamber door. No, too on the nose for our current situation.

So then I thought maybe POE could be embedded in a long answer, the way the themers were.
Like “Riding the popo express” or “Bringing the popo energy.”

I have now moved on to just doing other things with my evening.

Was only three minutes off my personal best when I got the dreaded “Not so fast, there!” POPUP.  Spent the next eight minutes searching for my mistake. 

I read 67D as “Princess Bride” actress, and didn’t remember Rita Wilson in that. So I put in her unknown twin sister dITA (sounds like a real person), thinking dENOUNCEMENT was a perfectly cromulent word. 

Oh well. Still under my average, somehow.
Instinctively started filling in ALEX for 8 Down and thought there was going to be a rebus when it didn't fit.
Pacifist's denouncement looked good so I fell one square short of success when I convinced myself there might have been an actress named Dita Wilson in The Runaway Bride.

I was so entertained doing this puzzle.  It wasn't easy for me, as it apparently was for others, Heck, it took me 50% longer than my average.  But the concept was so clever, and the misdirects so sly, I couldn't help but enjoy it the entire time that it took to hear the happy music.
Did it without looking anything up!

[This is only marginally on topic, so, eds., feel free to delete.]

Whilst solving this most excellent crossword, I was reminded (at 16D, to be specific, Works, works, works) of Back to the Future: The Musical. There is a song, It Works, sung by Doc Brown, that is absolutely fabulous. In the unlikely event you can't make it to the West End to see it, at least check out the soundtrack, definitely worth repeated listening.

Often times circles in the answers are not pertinent to the clues and just provide a bonus upon completion.  This time the circles were integral to the solution and I attacked those clues by shifting my attention to the downs that crossed the circled squares.  It was interesting to have my usual solving pattern  disrupted.  I enjoyed the change of pace.  I enjoyed MOUSEERADICATOR for CAT.
Totally worn out!

Okay perhaps I'm missing something but after reading the column it appears not.

Wasn't the theme here kind of terrible and awful?  Just completely arbitrary phrases chosen because they contain a short associated word?  That's it?

The only truly common phrase in the bunch is "none times out of ten".  The rest are just awkwardly worded and plucked out of nowhere.  What the deuce.  Maybe it's a joke I'm missing.

The overall puzzle was fine, perhaps a bit easy for a Sunday.  But this purported "theme".  Wow, there's not much there there.  :(

I had a slightly different problem solving this puzzle. I started on my iPad in dark mode, and the circles just don't show up well. Still managed to get two thirds of the puzzle done before I gave up and moved to the Mac to finish it, which went fairly quickly.

It was much easier to pick up on the theme answers and hidden words being able to actually see the circles.

Nice sophomore effort, Mike, and thank you.

As noted by Fagan and Becker, legal consultants for Fangord Forest Construction:

On a Tuesday' you start gunnin' for the SLOUCH who stole your DESSERT.
And you'd CASTAREALLYLONGLOOK but you want to leave work unhurt. 
Your coworkers all sing, "TRYIT" as their APPETITES compete,
So you tried to grin and BEHR it as they TORE into your sweet.

SKIP lunch my friend, KEN, NINETIMESOUTOFTEN, 
GUTS growlin' 'round and 'round
You hid it when, KEN? they'll eat it EGAN.

When your PRINT FELLTO find your LASER then find your ITPRO friend,
You're not his TOPRANKINGROYAL, he'll SKIP you to the end.
Then you chant a little MANTRA at the ALTAR of your LABORS,
All the time, the pro he's thinkin' you're a MOUSEERADICATOR, yeah

SLOG to the end, Ken, NINETIMESOUTOFTEN, EDITS waiting, won't be found
SLOG to the end, KEN, do it EGAN

Now you say you're not an OUTKAST but your SOBS CLOUD your working plans.
Then you find the DOOR is UNSHUT, you ASSAIL the HR man.
The HRREP is thinking "GODNO!" while you DRONE of POTPIES and ignored labels.
In a flash, he calls the POPO, "I NEWT KEN must be unstable!"
First I had TYKE for "consideration in the dating scene"  but fixed it with the cross of APPETITE. Then it showed up again at the bottom 😆! Some are TYKE TYPEs and others, NYET.
Never heard of the phrase "Not worth A SOU"!   The clue "Not worth ___" would have been more appropriate if expanded to: "Not worth ____ (like this clue)".
hella easy.  like a big tuesday.

Fun puzzle. I originally had GAbor before GARBO. Way before my time and my guess with just GA wasn’t too far off, so easy to fix. I finished but still had one error that took me forever to flyspeck. I had DoPE for 36D [Fool] which gave me GoTS for 40A [Takes down to the studs]. For whatever reason, I kept gliding right over that erroneous O and ended up finishing at just over an hour 😬 🤦🏼‍♀️ 

Loved [Unlocked?] for BALD 🧑🏼‍🦲 

Congratulations on a solid sophomore endeavor, Mike.

Did anyone else notice the typo in 110A? Pretty sure the word is spelled ERATICATOR! 🤣 (Sorry. My husband didn't laugh either. He did, however, love having an excuse to recite "CASEY at the Bat") Random thoughts in no particular order: Do you think 10A was inspired by the Wordplay comments section? Clues that made me laugh when I figured out the answers: Ax handlers, perhaps Entertainer who doesn't sound very selfish? Unlocked? Other cool things I noticed: LABORS next to DRONE "Things you hope your dinner guests bring" next to MERLOT. I really wanted 60A to be goat. And finally, my current puzzle-inspired earworm, which is neither "Rikki Don't Lose That Number" nor "Hey Ya," although that one's going through my head right now too. Enjoy! https://youtu.be/yg8116aeD7E?si=3QV_hCeCB05vAqqE

I set a new personal Sunday best with this one.
Less than 1/3 of my average (although that has probably had a few "puzzle left open overnight" snafus.)
I ate this puzzle like it was made of cheese! Very satisfying!

I was SO happy not to have to flyspeck this Sunday.  I have the past three or four, and it's really tedious.

So, I guess the lesson is, just don't make mistakes.

I was quite surprised to fill in the grid in a decent time and get the gold star on completion. I’ve gotten used to solving Sunday puzzles on my desktop computer, but we’re away from home, so it was the iPad or nothing. That grid looks pretty small compared to what I’m used to. Toss in circled letters (which are hard for me to see sometimes) and I was sure I would have a typo. 

But except for PACIFIST’S RENOUNCEMENT, I got the theme answers fairly quickly. That one was slow to come, because I had cOPs instead of POPO.

I really enjoyed the theme despite that slowdown. Thanks, Mr. Hobin!

I thought myself CLUED in for obscure and SEA instead of SUN but of course it just wasted time. 

I have chosen to do a US puzzle so I shouldn’t complain too much but BEHR 🤮

In any case it was all fine by the end. Just took longer that the trick required 

Thanks

I wonder... Has anybody ever actually uttered the word "unshut"? Google autocorrect was so confused by it just now that it "corrected" it to some gibberish, apparently considering even that a less unusual option.

Anyway. This was the first Sunday puzzle I felt like completing in many weeks. I needed to look up some trivia (especially the multiple trivia entries crossing the mysterious DRAKE), but I almost enjoyed the whole experience. 

I was quite proud I had no idea what superstitious people throw over their shoulders - whatever it is, it won't make any difference, anyway. Few things annoy me as much as belief in actual magic or luck.

Today was really fun! 

I actually LOL'ed at 14A Unlocked?
BALD!!! great clue!
Loved this one! When I let go of the MOnStERAnImATOR - apparently his name is mAT - it finally fell into place. :-)
Cops instead of popo was a problem.  The theme answers were the hardest part of the puzzle.  Took 27% less time than average.

Wow. Just - WOW! Typical tough workout for me, but... hard to imagine what it must have taken to construct a puzzle like this. It would have taken a lot of searching and pondering to come up with any answer that fit the trick, but then... 

...one grid-spanning entry and then three pairs of answers with both of the answers in each pair being of the same length, so that they could be fit in the usual top to bottom balanced puzzle. And... all of the theme answers appearing for the first time. That's just... amazing. 

And.. this is Mr. Hobin's second puzzle. The first one was also a Sunday and was another unique and amazing piece of work. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

Well, after I filled in a theme answer for the first time, my jaw happily dropped at seeing what was going on, and I thought, “Oh. VERY clever.  This is going to be fun!”  And it was.  

Answer as clue.  Answer in answer.  Sweet wordplay!

Sweetened even more by some lovely serendipities.  Rhyming pairs COCO / POPO and HUGO / TOGO.  The PuzzPair© of MANTRA and OMS.

Then the inspiring backstory.  Constructor accidentally falls upon a theme, spends weeks coming up with a set of theme answers – through brainwork alone, rather than computer coding, and while I have nothing against using coding to find theme answers, I feel an inner fist pump when I learn that it was all done manually, as it were.

Then, constructor continues the brain-only work, spending SIX MONTHS to come up with the perfect clue to use on all the theme answers.  Such patience and persistence! As I said, inspiring.

For me, a feel-good Sunday, for which I’m eminently grateful.  Thank you, Mike!

A cute one today:

Strands #483
“Hue are my sunshine”
🏳️‍🌈🔵🟣🟢
🟡🟠🔴

Long story, short
could have been the title.
And after the first two themers, I thought it was going to be about The Lord of the Rings, which would be a really long story, short.

46D  ____ ball. Has to be HAIR ball, right? 
From the MOUSE ERADICATOR.

Bring to the country, I left the door UNSHUT.

Fuzz to POPO, that slang gapped over multiple generations.


Enjoyed the puzzle, Mike.
FYI: 6 down, Girl in Don’t Lose My Number is no girl at all. The song is about Steely Dan’s friend Eric Clapton.

That was so much fun to solve!

(Will my other comment ever be released? Stay tuned.)

This one fell flat for me. Solved it, and liked the thematic concept, but not the execution. Would have insisted that all the words being defined were at least five letters long, and were not entirely contained in just one of the words in the definition. Quite surprised this was accepted for publication. POPO next to ASOU was especially bad.

Hope others liked this one a lot more than I did.

I struggled with this one. I didn’t know quite a few down clues so the theme solutions, except the first one, took me a long time. 
Some words, like SLOUCH and DOPE aren’t very familiar, the initialisms and names also. As for POPO! Would never have got that. 
I can appreciate the cleverness of the theme and the clues, like BALD, but I was hampered by expecting a LOTR theme, as I could see ENT.
This is exactly what I want from a Sunday! great cluing and a fun theme!

It took me a while to find a toehold but once-hold here but once I did…and once I understood how to approach the theme answers…I found this delightful. Even beyond the theme “clues” there were a few clues that tickled me: “Ax handlers, for short.” “Unlocked.” “Hair-raising.”  Nicely done.
Delightful trick. Made it tough but fun. I didn't get them all, but the MOUSE ELIMINATOR did show how to go about it. Extremely clever.
That there was a really fun puzzle and a great way to start out a hot Sunday.
Very easy Sunday puzzle, but POPO?  Who says that?

Part I of 2
I'm so happy for one final reference to Mario Bros!

Did as expected on the links for me is finishing in under 100, or lost all but one golf ball in the woods.

California is well represented this week, as well. Their newts, their tremendously popular Angelica (not Huston), and their idea of sobriety. Love it!

When I saw Zither, my first thought was “dulcimer,” leading to lute. That quickly made a lyre out of me. Mike the Master of Puns, you're still the KING… trust me.

I've heard of not being worth a “sod”, which I know is a subtle English expletive, but never a sou. Having once been in the employ of a British telecom giant, I would chuckle at their pronunciation of herb, especially when driving past a (or an) Herb shop. Their pronunciation of a router, versus ours, equally chuckle-worthy.

Skee and nerf balls… my god, don't ever confuse the two when playing backyard ball with your 4-year old! And don't bring the wrong one to the arcade.

Eton always stumps me, mainly because we have an Elon University in North Carolina. I get the two confused, so I have to remember that Chateau ELAN is an hour or so down the Interstate, and also contains an L.

Following the completion of the puzzle by our solvers today, please stay tuned for a series of important renouncements.

“A crossword puzzle needs clues. I’m cancelling my subscription.”
“Too much crosswordese. I’m switching to Connections.”
“Too easy. Off to WAPO.”
“So many renouncements! I’m quitting the comments.”
Those are not my opinions. I thought it was fun.

Much to my surprise, the 1A clue jumped up, crying, "Oooh!  Ooh!" So I started the puzzle there...  and since I usually work down and to the right, TOLKIE-- could only be one thing:  TOLKEIN TREE CREATION!
Ha,ha, that correction was the final corner bit that I entered.
This was delightful fun....well, except for UNSHUT and POPO.

I sort of miss our rehab projects...  (fixer-uppers are cheaper if you do the work yourselves.)  I'm very good with dry-wall mud. 
Also, BEHR really is good paint.
What a fun puzzle! I enjoyed it a lot!

That was fun.  My solve went in waves of sections.  Felt like how a puzzle is supposed to feel.  There were sections that baffled me at first, and everything came together. 

Really enjoyed the theme.  Made it so I could really enjoy the clues and the answers on our home near the sun.
No disrespect to KEN Jennings, but was anyone else initially surprised that the Jeopardy! answer at 8-Down had only three letters, and therefore ALEX wouldn't work?
Once I stopped trying to fit in OURmOMEntiNTHESUN things got easier. I felt really hip knowing POPO. Maybe it’s a DC thing LOL. My final problem was the dITA/RITA thing that others have commented on.
Flew right through this...59 sec. off my Sunday PB. Now I regret each sip of coffee, and the quick texts I answered! Lovely Sunday fun. Stay cool, crossworders.

It’s the day after the night before. I’m still a little bleary from the inferno that was the barn dance on one of the hottest nights of the year. Spent another two hours cleaning up this morning before I could finally crash out with the Sunday puzzle.

Given all that, not surprising that I struggled to work out the clue-in-clue theme. I needed Caitlin’s help to get me started, but once I got 49A in I had fun working out the others. As a LOTR geek my favourite naturally is 29A, what a great way to clue an otherwise so-so entry. It didn’t help that I spelled the name RIcKy. That held me up a tad.

I was fascinated to discover which plant we pronounce differently to you on the other side of the pond, then chuckled to find HERB. Back in the 80’s we were addicted to Dallas. I couldn’t understand what Pamela was ordering when she would always ask for ‘urb tea’ Apart from (to my delicate ear) the odd pronunciation, what tea would you like sweetie? There are dozens of Herb teas! I’m drinking a Moroccan mint and gunpowder green as I write. Delicious and refreshing on another heavy, humid day.
The editors missed a nice opportunity to clue 116-Across (ONCE) as "At that point" to couple with 118-Across "At this point.
35 down tricked me. With the reference to "god" thought it had to be "Lord."
I loved this puzzle! It was a fun brain tickler to start a leisurely Sunday morning. I was really impressed by the theme!
I really thought that "Did as expected on the links", at 47D, was going to be CLICKED. So clever, so wrong.

[Unlocked?] made me laugh out loud.

I loved seeing OUTKAST in the puzzle, as well as COCO. LABORS right next to DRONE seems appropriate, but I'm not sure bagpipes DRONE so much as screech. I once heard a writer describe the sound of a bagpipe as "like a goose with its foot caught in an escalator."
Surprised that 34D (RECUR) was not clued as a revealer, since the theme is recursive clues.

PO PO pitiful me
All those cOPs wouldn’t let me be.

Did I zip through this one? GOD NO.
But once I UNSHUT my mind, I had a good time.

D-backs - solves to ARI - could someone explain please?

Also AFL to CIO?

Remaining - TOGO?

Ta.

I had to sleep on this after a busy tiring Saturday, only 1/3 filled in. But it went fast on Sunday morning.  As I gradually understood the idea, I thought this one would be great for getting a noob into the thinking in the direction of rebuses. 
 NINETIMESOUTOFTEN a baseball game doesn’t go into overtime.  All I know of Tolkien I learned from crosswords. 
Loved this.  Thanks.
Excellent! I needed help with a couple of entries, but that’s on me. Fun and clever. More please.
14A had my wife laughing out loud when she got it. She is currently untressed during chemo, and enjoys things in the puzzle that resonate.

Yesterday's Connections - I got none. Usually get at least one!
Help please with:
Results of a traffic violation - BOOT?
Great many - DROVE?

Also a SCORE is 20, not really a great many.

Also never seen anyone throw a BONE to a dog to fetch, only given to chew on! Doubt a dog would bring it back...
Completely delightful Sunday romp. Many thanks Mike!
Today’s puzzle was an absolute joy! Unless I have suddenly gotten a lot smarter, it was clever, well-constructed, and did not require any knowledge of popular culture since the Beatles. Thank you!
TIL POPO. I couldn't shake the belief that _OP_ had to be COPS until I finally figured out what those blanks were the first letters of. I'll stick with COPS when I'm talking anyway.

Fun idea and well-constructed, but the clues for the most part were pretty straight-forward and unimaginative so it was a breezy solve.

Or maybe I'm just extra sharp this morning because I breezed through the Bee too!

Bottom across word of the Mini; um, what? 😂

Beautiful Strands today ☺️

Nice puzzle. 

The trick was interesting. 

Pretty breezy aside from POPO occupying much less space in my cognitive map than COPS.

"Makes amends?" for EDITS was diabolical. That mini-block of squares was the last to fill for me. I not sure if it was the un-clues in the long themers, but this puzzle solved like a second Saturday for me...and I mean that in a good way.

Anyone who thinks ICE SKATES "barely scratch the surface" has never played hockey. There's a reason why the Zamboni has to come out after every period. But it was rather clever, so I'll allow it.
So, so 110% positive that it couldn't be anything other than Mr Potato Head's Ear.  So very, very wrong.
“Unclued” (more properly, “self clued”) is a nice twist. Of course this meant that the crossing downs had to be on the easy side, so the whole puzzle was breezy but rewarding.
The picture of the man oiling the to-go order of roses will stay with me for a long time.
I didn't understand this one at all. Maybe I need to stick to the easy Monday - Thursday ones.

Love, love, love!  I am always lost and dense with the concept of a theme, even a Sunday theme.  This one just fell into my lap, or my eyes, actually!  

What an entertaining and fun puzzle! Just challenging enough to keep me interested, and easy enough for me to have the hope that I'll finish without looking things up.  Thank you!

The constructor's starter, 29A, is a top entry for me. I always enjoyed the creatures of Middle Earth like the Ents, Tom Bombadil, and on the dark side, the Balrogs. They lent a sense of living ancient history to the world. Interestingly, "ent" is Old English for "giant." 

For those who struggeled with PO-PO (I had COPS first too), I recommend listening to some Outkast and others in the genre for context. The OED's earliest evidence for it is from the the 1991 DJ Quik song "Deep." 

Overall, a fun puzzle with a clever theme and some great fill.
Had VIKKI don't lose that number for way too long.
I had DoPE instead of DUPE for fool. Took me over 10 minutes to find the mistake

Showed my age on this one:  "Fuzz" just had to be COPS!  And thought  those clouds might be CIRRA (???), so I was stuck on trying to find some kind of "California"-related --FAST--.  ("What the heck is in vogue now?")  Ridiculous train of thought kept me in dark for a longish time. Sometimes you just have to RENOUNCE those wrong rabbit holes.

This puzzle was fun, and kept me on my toes with the bottom theme entries, which needed careful consideration to fill in.

For me, the nontheme clues were almost all pushovers, so I would have preferred at least a little more resistance from them.

And not a fan of "Works, works, works" as a clue for LABORS, which strikes me as tedious overkill.

(I also wonder before reading the Constructor's Notes whether someone who considers 93 million miles away to be NEAR must be an astronomer (;-)>.)

But fun, and took longer than my Sunday average to figure out the all the creative meta theme clues.

At first I had a ninth of the puzzle unfilled after an hour, but when I read Caitlin and she gave me OUR HOME ON EARTH NEAR THE SUN, I got POPO instead of Cops and the rest filled in. Thanks, Mike Hobin. The Tolkien reference gave a nice EARTHy feel to it! And go CATS! 🐈‍⬛
Loved this one! Very clever and entertaining.

I haven't read all of the previous 344 comments, so someone may have already mentioned this. In addition to doing the current daily puzzles, I'm working my way back through the archives and am now in March, 2016. Coincidentally, on the 6th of that month, David J. Kahn had exactly the same type of clue-within-a-clue as today's puzzle. A good example: "Comrade of Mercutio", which has "Romeo" embedded in it.

Loved everything about this puzzle except the use of FIST to describe a pacifist's renouncement. Where I came from, if someone showed you their fist it meant they wanted to fight - to make war not love.
A bit of a slog
Fun puzzle, thanks.  Finally solved it through trial and error on the cross of COCO, which I never saw, and NINETIMESOUTOFTEN. Good one
Loved this puzzle!  But I was stumped on POPO--never heard this word.

Loved the puzzle, but had to flyspeck when I thought I was finished. Somehow I had changed a stray letter that I had already put in correctly. I looked at every down and across answer and finally found the spot way at the bottom, where I had originally put in ETON crossing TO GO, but somehow in my travels around a big grid a letter was changed. Sorry, that was way too many words. All I really needed to say is that it was challenging and a very clever theme.
EGAD where's the Natick POPO? Caitlin needs to be advised on what a Natick is! 🤣🚓

Just received an email from the NYT indicating that the yearly rate for GAMES access is going to be raised from $30 to $50, starting Aug 2025. What is disappointing is that last year I got an email from the NYT indicating that the yearly rate for GAMES access was going to be raised from $19.97 to $30. What is even more disappointing is the wording of the current email is almost an exact rehash of the previous email. 

To be clear the entertainment value is worth the $50 a year. What is concerning is the significant jump from $19.97 to $50 in just one year and the cloned email. What the heck is going on at the NYT?
The problem with trying to start crosswords when you're tired, is you put fAkE in for "Like a $2 bill" and you don't notice it until much later during review.

@Barry Ancona

The stats you cited certainly bear out what I said.  But currently, those percentages have moved the needle even farther towards easiness.  As of right now:

86% of users solved faster than their Sunday average.
52% solved much faster (>20%) than their Sunday average.

@Barry Ancona That's a biased set -- the slower solvers wouldn't have finished yet. Early results skewing towards faster results is natural but not proof of anything. 

(That said, I came in under my average time today, but that's partly because when I first started the Sundays took *hours* but I got faster as I practiced. Most puzzles at this point are under average for me; exceptions are mostly when I have to flyspeck.)

Likewise. If I don’t beat my average by say 10%, I consider that I was … slower than average. I’m only approaching a year as a daily solver, so I’m still picking up your tricks. Before that I was an occasional solver. 

I like the elegant insight about slower results coming in later. I have a vague feeling that there are other examples, in the wider world I mean, of that phenomenon. I wonder if statisticians have a name for it. Or actuaries.

Isabeau,

Of course it is. That's why I wrote:
"The early precincts are reporting now:"

@Isabeau

And that's why I followed up with updated statistics, that support the original assertion even more strongly.

@LBG

Yeah, yeah, yeah.  You missed the point.

How well one does in relation to his/her average has nothing to do with how fast that average is. 

So later results may show more people beating their average, or fewer people.  How fast they solved is irrelevant here.
@Barry Ancona I found them a little awkward too, they took me a fair bit of sussing out.

@Francis How to solve Wordle every time: 1. Start with SLANT. (STERN is also good.) 2. If you get no letters (after SLANT), guess CORED second. 3. Do not be afraid to guess a word that couldn't win but eliminates several common remaining letters, especially if you have too many options remaining for the letters you've already revealed. (For example, if you have _ASTE, it could be W, H, P, B, T, C, so guess BATCH. Then you may get the right letter, or at least eliminate four of them.) 4. If guessing to win, don't guess plurals ending in S or past tense verbs ending in -ED (unless they're more commonly adjectives, like TIRED). 5. Find a list of most common letters in each position of a five letter word (yes, they're out there) and use it to select your letters carefully. N may be a top-five letter overall, but it's near the bottom for the first letter. Y may be a bottom-five letter overall, but it's the second most common last letter. 6. Practice! Try Duotrigordle. You get to solve 32 Wordles simultaneously. It's not as hard as you think. Always choose SLANT and CORED first before even trying to do the individual games. Then choose WIMPY, GIMPY or BUMPY as your third guess. After doing that, you start playing the individual games. You may find that several of them are done or practically done by then. Any info you glean applies to all the games. It's a lot of fun! https://duotrigordle.com/

@Jane Wheelaghan

The AFL-CIO was formed in 1955 when the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations merged. It was big news. Older folks still think of it as two groups, so cluing for just one half of the initialism feels appropriate. '55 was before my time, but even into the 70s, news reports often noted the AFL and CIO factions of the group. 
Most unionized workers in the US are in a union that's part of the AFL-CIO.
It still plays a huge role in politics, often on the small-ell liberal side of things, and you will hear it mentioned in presidential campaigns. That's why the initialism is well-known enough to Americans to be in a crossword puzzle.

@Jane Wheelaghan

So were my parents... Dad was in the CWA (Communications Workers of America) and Mom was in the teachers' union. Unions have gotten a bad rap in this country of late.
